title: Police use of Stop-and-Search rose by a third in last year
text:
The police's use of stop-and-search rose by a third in the last year as officers used the power 383,629 times after the Home Office relaxed its rules.

The rise comes after the Government widened its 'reasonable suspicion' scope to cut knife crime.

Most of the searches in the last year, 279,601 (almost 73 per cent), resulted in no further action being taken.

This is up from 197,725 (70.1 per cent) in the same period a year earlier. There was an overall arrest rate of 15 per cent, amounting to 58,876 arrests.

Police stop and search two people at the Notting Hill Carnival in London on August 27 last year

The figures released by the Home Office on Thursday look at all stop-and-search powers police have under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984, the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994 and the Terrorism Act 2000.

It comes as figures today revealed that the number of knives on Britain's streets are at the highest in a decade.

More than 22,000 thugs were caught with knives or dangerous weapons in the last year and the number of immediate jail sentences are at their highest level since records began, figures show.

In the 12 months to the end of June, 22,306 offences were formally dealt with by the justice system in England and Wales, up from 21,314 on the same period the previous year.

The police's use of stop-and-search rose by a third in the last year as officers used the power 383,629 times after the Home Office relaxed its rules to combat knife crime (file photo)

This is the highest number on record since 2010 when 22,689 offences were dealt with, but it is not the highest level ever recorded as a year earlier, in the same period in 2009, the figure was 27,225.

In March this year, then-Home Secretary Sajid Javid simplified the procedure officers are required to follow in order to use stop-and-search.

Section 60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act now enables the police to execute the powers without reasonable grounds of suspicion if they anticipate serious violence.

The change was rolled out across seven forces in areas that accounted for more than 60 per cent of knife crime.

Javid's fundamental changes were to reduce the level of authorisation required to execute a Section 60.

He also lowered the degree of certainty required to do so, meaning officers can now stop and search suspects if they think serious violence 'may' occur as opposed to 'will' occur.
description: Of the searches police have conducted over the past 12 months, just 15 per cent resulted in an arrest after the Home Office gave police greater powers to combat the UK's knife crime epidemic.
